You are here:

SALESFORCE HELP
DOCS
INDUSTRIES COMMON FEATURES GUIDE
Create a Data Processing Engine Definition

You can create multiple Data Processing Engine definitions based on your business requirements.

REQUIRED EDITIONS AND USER PERMISSIONS
Available in: Lightning Experience
Available in: Enterprise, Unlimited, and Professional Editions with Financial Services Cloud, Manufacturing Cloud, Loyalty Management, Net Zero Cloud, Rebate Management, Accounting Subledger, or Provider Search in Health Cloud


USER PERMISSIONS NEEDED
To create a definition:	
Customize Application
Modify All Data

Before creating a definition, understand the business requirements and the sequence to create nodes and input variables.

From Setup, in the Quick Find box, enter Data Processing Engine, and then select Data Processing Engine.
Click New.
Provide these details.
FIELD	DESCRIPTION
Name and API Name	Enter the name of the Data Processing Engine definition. The API name is auto-populated based on the name that you enter. You can’t change the name and API name after you save your definition for the first time.
Description	Enter a description of your definition.
Process Type	

Select a process type based on the licenses available in your Salesforce org. Data Processing Engine can process data differently based on the rules set by the license. Process types ensure that definitions follow the validations and limits of the associated license. Process types can also provide exclusive capabilities. Process types are available for these licenses:

Loyalty Management
Rebate Management
Financial Services Cloud
Manufacturing Cloud
Net Zero Cloud

To run the definition without any rules associated with a license, select the process type as Standard.


Use this data processing engine as a template?	To create a read-only definition, select this option. Your colleagues and partners can make a copy of the template definitions and change them based on their business requirements.
After you enter the definition details, click Next.
Select one of these runtime platforms:
CRM Analytics: Select to use CRM Analytics to transform your data or if the data is from a CRM Analytics dataset.
Data Cloud: Select to use Data Cloud to transform your data or if the data is from Data Model Objects (DMO), Data Lake Objects (DLO), or Calculated Insights Objects (CIO). In the Data Space menu, select the data space to use objects within that data space in the definition.
For more information about runtimes, see Data Processing Engine Runtimes.
Click Done.

The definition is created. These steps show a brief workflow of how you typically set up and run a definition:

Create Data Source nodes.
Create input variables.
This option is only available with the CRM Analytics runtime.
Create the required nodes in the sequence to be processed.
Create a separate Writeback Objects node for each object or Analytics dataset that you want to write the results back to.
Save the definition.
Activate the definition.
Validate the definition to make sure that it’s correct and can be run. Any errors in the definition are highlighted when you try to activate a definition. Warnings are also provided. Warnings help you identify issues that you can choose to fix or ignore.

After you activate the definition, it’s available to run in Flows or from the definition's builder.

Create a Data Processing Engine Node
Add a node to your Data Processing Engine definition to transform data. Each node type transforms your data in a different way. For example, you can use a node to join two datasets, calculate a field value using formulas, or append a dataset to another dataset.
Configure a Data Processing Engine Node
Configure nodes in a definition to set up how data is transformed.
Create or Edit a Data Processing Engine Definition in a JSON File
Build a Data Processing Engine definition in a JSON file and then upload it to the builder. You can also download definitions, make changes, and then upload the updated definition.
View Reference Nodes
Select a node and view the details of other nodes that currently reference elements of it, such as node sources and mapped fields. These nodes that reference the selected node are known as reference nodes. If you make changes to a node, it’s helpful to know its reference nodes to anticipate any changes that need to be made to them, too.
Why Does a Node Indicate That Removed Fields Are Referenced in a Node after the References Are Removed?
When you remove fields from a node, ensure that the removed fields aren't referenced by any other node in the definition. The node in which you've already deleted references to the removed fields is used as a source by another node in which the removed fields are still referenced. To resolve this issue, go to the node in which you've deleted references to the removed fields. Next, find the nodes that use the current node as source and reference the removed field. Go to the nodes that still reference the removed fields, and then delete the references.
